Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12325 (1)
Section (1) An agency shall recommend to the department the appropriate
Description licensing action consistent with facts contained in the foster home
evaluation and any special evaluations.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency completed an investigation that is not consistent with the
findings of fact.
Investigation The complainant is the area manager as the information was submitted
to DCWL Disciplinary Action Unit (DAU). A phone conference occurred
on 12/14/22 to discuss allegation and investigation.
Administrator was interviewed via TEAMS on 12/15/22. Administrator
reported having very little knowledge about the special evaluation (SE).
The SE was completed as a courtesy due to both foster parents being
employees of other DHHS offices. Administrator recalled Licensing
Worker was assigned to the SE and found the process challenging due
to the foster parents being DHHS county office employees, children’s
services involvement, and having multiple counties involved, but also
needing to maintain confidentiality.
Licensing Worker was interviewed face-to-face at the agency on
12/16/22. Licensing Worker reported that upon completion of the SE,
2

Children’s Services determined their case was “confirmed”. However,
the family would not be placed on Central Registry due to changes in
the Child Protection Law effective 11/1/22. Licensing Worker reported
he spoke with Licensing Supervisor 1 about the recommendation in the
investigation and determined a recommendation of a 1st provisional
license may be appropriate, rather than a recommendation to revoke
the license. Licensing Worker indicated this recommendation was
initially made based on several factors: this was the first incident in the
foster home; the foster parents were transparent, remorseful, and
forthcoming with information, accepted responsibility and committed to
rectifying the situation; foster care workers and parents of the children
placed in the home had very positive experiences with the foster
parents and no concerns; the foster parents self-implemented a
corrective action plan (CAP) before the SE commenced; the foster
parents began couples counseling, individual therapy, training about
parenting skills, and contact with a physician to review a prescription
medication as the foster parents believed the medication caused the
foster parent to act in an uncharacteristic manner.
Licensing Worker stated his understanding of the new child protection
law was that a foster parent placed on central registry automatically
meant revocation of a foster home license. However, a “confirmed”
case gave the agency some discretion about the recommendation.
Licensing Worker included that the SE report does not allow for the
worker to explain the rational for the recommendation. It was believed if
DAU did not agree with the recommendation or had questions, the
agency would be contacted to discuss if another recommendation was
more appropriate.
When asked if anyone instructed or pressured Licensing Worker about
the recommendation, he stated no. Licensing Worker reported there
was a lot of communication and discussion among Children’s Services
Worker and agency directors about all options and what they would
mean for the foster parents/DHHS employees. The discussion was due
to the Child Protection Law changing in the middle of this investigation
and how it impacted findings for Children’s Services. Licensing Worker
did not feel like there was pressure for a certain recommendation.
Licensing Worker stated, in his opinion, the Children’s Services worker
is a person of great integrity and could not have been swayed one way
or another if anyone tried. After receiving the findings from children’s
services, Licensing Worker spoke with Licensing Supervisor 1 about
the investigation and agreed on the recommendation, indicating this is
the recommendation they would have made regardless of the foster
parents being DHHS staff.
Licensing Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face on 12/16/22 at the
agency. Licensing Supervisor 1 stated with the recent changes to Child
4

Protection Law it is still clear that placement on Central Registry would
require revocation. However, the supervisor believed if the case was
confirmed, the agency was not required to recommend revocation.
Licensing Supervisor 1 stated she and Licensing Worker determined
their initial recommendation by looking at the rule violations, if they
were correctable, and how the foster parents could come into
compliance. Licensing Supervisor 1 felt a CAP alone was not enough,
but revocation may be too much. With the foster parents already taking
steps to come into compliance, before violations were determined, the
agency believed compliance could be possible with a CAP and six-
month increased supervisory period during a 1st provisional license.
Licensing Supervisor 1 felt the 1st provisional recommendation was
appropriate for this situation, citing the same reasons Licensing Worker
reported. Licensing Supervisor 1 added that the foster home’s capacity
had also been decreased. Licensing Supervisor 1 believed if DAU
disagreed with the recommendation, they may have a conference to
discuss it.
When asked if anyone pressured the agency into one recommendation
versus another, Licensing Supervisor 1 stated she did not feel
pressured. However, there were meetings held with the directors of the
counties the foster parents worked for, in which the directors were clear
they did not want their staff placed on central registry. Children’s
Services Worker discussed how the findings may have gone one way
before the 11/1/22 law change, and another after the change. Licensing
Supervisor 1 stated the Children’s Services Worker was not someone
who would let people sway her recommendation, no matter how
unhappy it made others.
Children’s Services Worker (CSW) was interviewed via TEAMS on
1/5/23. CSW explained the investigation findings did not meet the
criteria for placement on Central Registry, therefore the case was
completed as “confirmed”. CSW clarified that prior to 11/1/22, this case
may have resulted in placement on Central Registry, but that likely
would have been decided by a supervisor. CSW stated there was no
injury to any children in the home and that would have been a
consideration.
Regardless, during the investigation, the family was very cooperative
and remorseful. CSW was impressed by their commitment and
determination to address the problems identified. CSW reported the
foster parents began taking classes, attending therapy, and spoke with
a physician immediately after the incident. CSW recently had contact
with the family again and found the home to be much more relaxed.
CSW stated she had high hopes for these parents as they have a lot of
love to give and the kids are doing well in the home. By all accounts
4

from foster care staff, parents, and school staff, this is a great foster
home. It is believed the situation requiring investigation likely happen
due to multiple stressors at once and a medical issue.
CSW reported she did not witness pressure from anyone toward
Licensing Worker 1 to make a specific recommendation. However,
during the investigation it was unclear if the investigation would be
completed before 11/1/22, or after. CSW reported the two agency
directors from the counties which the foster parents were employed,
indicated they wanted CSW to wait until after 11/1/22 to complete the
investigation. This was likely due to the impact CSW’s findings would
have on employment of both staff. CSW informed the directors that she
would not delay her findings and she would make the appropriate
recommendation, regardless of the fact the people being investigated
were also DHHS staff. CSW said she explained this to the directors on
a few occasions. In the end, after interviews were completed and report
revisions made, the report was not approved until after 11/1/22.
Therefore, resulting in a “confirmed case” for the foster parents. The
directors took some time but came to understand the reasoning for
CSW’s findings.
Licensing Supervisor 2 was interviewed via TEAMS on 1/10/23.
Licensing Supervisor 2 is from the agency that holds the license for the
foster home that was investigated. This agency is also the employer of
one of the foster parents. Licensing Supervisor 2 stated she was
supportive of the agency’s recommendation for a 1st provisional and felt
it was appropriate for the investigation findings. Licensing Supervisor 2
reported this foster home had not had any prior concerns; no pattern or
trends to consider. The family was going through a very difficult time,
which they took responsibility for and were addressing.
Licensing Supervisor 2 reported she did not witness anyone trying to
influence a decision made by the agency regarding the license
recommendation. There were several open conversations about what
may or may not happen, and why decisions were made the way they
were. There were a lot of “what if’s” in discussion as the law change
created new territory for all people involved and they were attempting to
understand what that meant. Licensing Supervisor 2 did not witness
anyone ask Children’s Services to delay their findings until after
11/1/22.
Documents reviewed:
Foster Home Special Evaluation 2022C0631296, completed by
Hillsdale DHHS on 12/7/22. The investigation determined a domestic
violence incident occurred between the foster parents, while one foster
parent was holding a child. The child was not injured. A violation of
Rule 9201(j) was cited, in addition to children services determining a
confirmed case. Initially the agency recommended a 1st provisional
4

license. However, after consultation with the DAU, the agency
recommended a revocation of the foster home license.
Analysis Based on the interviews there is no evidence the agency made an
improper recommendation. The agency made a recommendation they
believed to be consistent with the findings of the investigation. There
was no evidence the agency was encouraged to make a different
recommendation due to the foster parent’s employment with DHHS.
Consultation:
Consultation was provided to Licensing Supervisor 1 to contact DCWL
whenever they have questions about a recommendation, or they are
unsure of which recommendation to make. Specifically, regarding
confirmed cases with Children’s Services, as this is a new process.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, and policy. It is recommended
that the current license status be continued.
